Indications and doses

Symptomatic relief of allergy such as hay fever and urticaria, Insomnia associated with urticaria and pruritus,

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    10–20 mg 2–3 times a day.
  • For adults
    25–50 mg (max. per dose 100 mg).
  • For children 2–4 years
    5 mg twice daily, alternatively 5–15 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 5–9 years
    5–10 mg twice daily, alternatively 10–25 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night.
  • For children 10–17 years
    10–20 mg 2–3 times a day, alternatively 25 mg once daily, dose to be taken at night, increased if necessary to 25 mg twice daily.

Emergency treatment of anaphylactic reactions,

By slow intravenous injection

  • For adults
    25–50 mg, to be administered as a solution containing 2.5 mg/mL in water for injections; maximum 100 mg per course.

Sedation (short-term use),

By deep intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    25–50 mg.
  • For adults
    25–50 mg.
  • For children 2–4 years
    15–20 mg.
  • For children 5–9 years
    20–25 mg.
  • For children 10–17 years
    25–50 mg.

Nausea, Vomiting, Vertigo, Labyrinthine disorders, Motion sickness,

By mouth

  • For adults
    20–25 mg, to be taken at bedtime on night before travel, repeat following morning if necessary.
  • For children 2–4 years
    5 mg, to be taken at bedtime on night before travel, repeat following morning if necessary.
  • For children 5–9 years
    10 mg, to be taken at bedtime on night before travel, repeat following morning if necessary.
  • For children 10–17 years
    20–25 mg, to be taken at bedtime on night before travel, repeat following morning if necessary.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Most manufacturers of antihistamines advise avoiding their use during pregnancy; however, there is no evidence of teratogenicity.

Use in the latter part of the third trimester may cause adverse effects in neonates such as irritability, paradoxical excitability, and tremor.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Avoid in severe liver disease—increased risk of coma.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use with caution.

Contra indications

  • Many antihistamines should be avoided in Acute porphyrias but promethazine is thought to be safe.
  • neonates: neonate (due to significant antimuscarinic activity) in neonates
  • children: should not be given to children under 2 years, except on specialist advice, because the safety of such use has not been established in children

Known side effects

General side effects

rare: Anaphylaxis, angioedema, angle-closure glaucoma, arrhythmias, blood disorders, bronchospasm, confusion, convulsions, depression, dizziness, extrapyramidal effects, hypersensitivity reactions, hypotension, liver dysfunction, palpitation, photosensitivity reactions, rashes, sleep disturbances, tremor,

notKnown: Antimuscarinic effects, blurred vision, drowsiness, dry mouth, gastro-intestinal disturbances, headache, psychomotor impairment, restlessness, urinary retention,

Specific side effects

notKnown: injection pain in adults,

In adults

Elderly patients are more susceptible to side-effects.

In children

Children are more susceptible to side-effects.

In adults

Drowsiness is a significant side-effect with most of the older antihistamines although paradoxical stimulation may occur rarely, especially with high doses or in children and the elderly. Drowsiness may diminish after a few days of treatment and is considerably less of a problem with the newer antihistamines.

In children

Drowsiness is a significant side-effect with most of the older antihistamines although paradoxical stimulation may occur rarely in children, especially with high doses. Drowsiness may diminish after a few days of treatment and is considerably less of a problem with the newer antihistamines.

Advice for patients and carers

Important safety information

MHRA/CHM advice (March 2008 and February 2009) Over-the-counter cough and cold medicines for children

Children under 6 years should not be given over-the-counter cough and cold medicines containing promethazine.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Epilepsy
  • : prostatic hypertrophy in adults
  • pyloroduodenal obstruction
  • severe coronary artery disease
  • susceptibility to angle-closure glaucoma
  • urinary retention
  • With intravenous use: avoid extravasation with intravenous injection

Unlicensed use

In children

Not licensed for use for sedation in children under 2 years.

Conditions when less suitable for prescribing

Promethazine is less suitable for prescribing for sedation.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

Promethazine Hydrochloride Tablets 10 mg or 25 mg may be prescribed.

Promethazine Hydrochloride Oral Solution (elixir) 5 mg/5 mL may be prescribed.

Exceptions to legal category

Prescription only medicine restriction does not apply to promethazine hydrochloride injection where administration is for saving life in emergency.

Prepared medicinal forms of PROMETHAZINE HYDROCHLORIDE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.
